title.narrative: Financial and Legal Sector Technical Assistance Project

description.narrative: The overall development objective of the project is to create a sound financial system and strengthened legal and judicial capacity that will ensure broad access to financial and related legal services.

sector.narrative: Judicial and other Dispute Resolution Mechanisms

condition.narrative: Establish and maintain a Project Implementation Unit
Establish and maintain a Project Steering Committee
Prepare Mid Term report of project progress

title.narrative: Time taken to register companies’ declines 8 days by project end.

comment.narrative: 60 days (DB2004) 47 days (DB2005)
DB 2013; reported by PMU NOvember 2012.No. of procedure (10), time (32 days) reduced by one day from DB2012. Cost has incrased to40.4% from 37.8% of income per capita.

title.narrative: The rate(s) of case clearances by Milimani Commercial Courts, or in respect of major types of commercial cases, improves significantly by at least 5 percent annually from 2011

comment.narrative: No baseline was established at appraisal

target.value: Case clearance increases by 5 percent annually

actual.value: rate of increase seems to be well above target, even accounting for some minor adjustments that may emerge. This is the first timeKenya has this data available; last few days of consultancy working on attribution aspects and fine tuning. Team will take it onfurther during ICR in coordination with JIP project team.

comment.narrative: Ongoing Consultancy to determine case clearance rate ending in a few days, but data already available. The absence of a baselineand updated survey and inventory of cases hampered past assessment of the improvements in the courts and case management. This willdetermine a case clearance ratio for Miimani Commercial Court. Preliminary data encouraging, as noted in annexes uploaded.

title.narrative: Proportion of financial institutions in compliance with capital adequacy ratios rises

comment.narrative: Number, percent compliance
96 percent compliant with CBK Capital Adequacy Ratios (CAR)

Source: PIU, based CBK BSD monitoring template;As at December 2012, all the 44 banks and mortgage finance company (Regulated FIs)had met the KSh.1bn Minimum Core Capital requirement, the Minimum Capital Adequacy Requirement (CAR), Core Capital to DepositRatiosand Liquidity Ratios (Minimum 20%). FIs also observed the maximum foreign exposure limit of 10%. Overall, the RegulatoryCapital toRisk-Weighted Assets (RWA) ratio has remained around 20%. The Banking sector remains well capitalized and highlyprofitable.

title.narrative: Non-Performing Loans (NPLs) drop to 8 percent of Total Loans (net of interest in suspense) by end of project.

comment.narrative: Source: CBK, PMU February 2013NPLs reduction to under 3%, in part through project support to strengthen legal and regulatoryframeworks in financial and related legal sector; strengthen capacity of the regulators and introduction of risk based supervision(RBS), coupled with strong Project Support at the beginning of the FLSTAP to prepare the state influenced banks for privatizationand change the reform agenda in Kenya (ncluding passing of Privatization Act with specific listing of the projects, compared toreluctance to even consider this as a possiibility in 2003) has been critical to the stability of the financial sector and is asignificant achievement.

title.narrative: Number of accounts in the financial sector increases to 15 million accounts by project end.

comment.narrative: Source: PMU, March 2013Includes deposit-taking MFIs; accounts in banks were 15,072,922The number of deposit accounts rose to17.617mn at 31 December 2012, compared to 14.25mn (31 December 2011) and 16.77mn (30 September 2012). The Project target of 15mnaccounts was met well over 6 months earlier than project close and is a near 7-fold increase in 7 years compared a mere 2,550,905despots accounts in 2005. This 7 - Fold increase in access (including DTMs) over 7 years evidences a transformational increase inaccess tobasic bank accounts and financial inclusion and has been mainly been realized by the explosion in access by the low incomesegment (previously unbanked and under banked). Project Interventions have led to improvements in the financial infrastructure,particularlybetter regulation, a more robust legal and regulatory environment, reform measures that have updated financial sectorlegislation and regulations; stronger supervision from project funded activities that have strengthen

title.narrative: Integrated debt management system is in place

baseline.value: Government debt management is divided between the MoF and CBK, with little coordination or consolidation of functions. Nocomprehensive debt management strategy developed.

target.value: Comprehensive debt management strategy Annual debt management reports issued.

comment.narrative: There may be changes expected from public financial management bill being assessed.

SOurce: PMU, WB debt management mission;MOF and CBK implemented reforms supported by FLSTAP (and PFMR project) that addressedstructural weaknesses in public debt management; introduced reforms to transform Debt Management Department (DMD) to a DebtManagement Office (DMO); reformed domestic debt markets to deepen the investor base, promoted secondary market trading andsupported developmentof a yield curve for Government securities; developed a Medium Term Debt Strategy (MTDS) (3rd Report June2011); continued implementation of the Government Securities Market Makers (GSMMs) - part of Primary Dealers (PD) framework; andsupport for Treasury Mobile Direct (TMD) to enable retail sales of Government Securities through mobile phones

title.narrative: Judicial sector strategic plan adopted and being implemented by the judiciary.

actual.value: JSP under implementation. JPIP project approved to implement new round of reforms building on achievements of FLSTAP.

comment.narrative: Source: PMU, March 2013Actual(Current)Judiciary Strategic Plan 2009 - 2013 approved and under implementation. The Strategic plansupported by the Project was used by the Judiciary to develop the new Judiciary Transformation Framework (2012-2016) developed asthe overarching blueprint for reforming and repositioning the Judiciary

title.narrative: Number of courses offered at the University of Nairobi School of Law and the Kenya School of Law on commercial and financial law rises.

baseline.value: 16 courses for the 2004/05 academic yearNone for KSL.

comment.narrative: Extensive Curriculum development supported by the Project

title.narrative: Credit extended to the private sector as a percentage of GDP increases to at least 37 percent by end of project.

comment.narrative: Source: CBK, PMU, March 2013.Achieved, but largely driven by macro factors. Other access to finance measures do reflect thebetter services for the population at large, in line wit the spirit of this indicator.

title.narrative: Interest rate spread between Average Deposit Rates and Lending Rates falls below 8 percent by end of project

comment.narrative: Source: CBK, PMU, November 2012

title.narrative: Comprehensive Financial Sector Reform and Development (CFSRF) strategies adopted by the Cabinet.

target.value: CFSRD approved by Cabinet, adopted for implementation

comment.narrative: Source: PMU, December 2012Comprehensive Financial Sector Reform &Development Strategy (CFSRD) submitted to MOF (Oct.2011) hasbeenadopted by MOF; and has been instrumental in guiding the development of the Medium Term Plan 2013-2017 (MTP2) for the FinancialServices Sector. The CFSRD is thus a critical Policy paper guiding development of the Financial Services Sector.

title.narrative: CBK’s compliance (Compliant or Largely Compliant) with Basel Core Principles (BCP) rises to at least 18 principles.

actual.value: At least 18, possibly more (AML, or other areas, TBC)

comment.narrative: No BCP compliance assessment was carried out for this ISR period. However, In the FSAP 2009 Update, the BCP Detailed AssessmentReport stated that the CBK had “made substantial progress in addressing the deficiencies highlighted in the 2003 FSAP”. As a resultof these improvements the number of principles that were assessed as Compliant or Largely Compliant increased to 18. Since theFSAP 2009 Update assessment took place, the authorities of Kenya have amended or issued important laws, such as the Central Bank ofKenyaAct, the Banking Act and the Proceeds of Crime and Anti-Money Laundering Act, and issued guidelines, most notably on riskmanagementand prudential matters and on prevention of the abuse of the financial system, to keep gradually addressing thevulnerabilities identified in previous assessments.While the actual degree of implementation of the improvements in the legalframework and the issuedguidelines by the banking system of Kenya will have to be evaluated on the field by means

title.narrative: Autonomy of Financial Sector Regulators (IRA, CMA, RBA, Saccos Regulatory Authority and CBK-BSD) established.

baseline.value: CMA, RBA partially autonomous; Commissioner of Insurance is a dept. of MoF; DPFB operated CBK though it has separate BoardJune2005.

target.value: CMA, RBA, IRA, CBK –BSD remain autonomous. SASRA more autonomous.

comment.narrative: Improved ICT/workflows at all institutions.

actual.value: CMA, RBA, IRA, CBK –BSD remain autonomous. SASRA more autonomous.

comment.narrative: SOurce: PMU; Dec 2013CMA, RBA, IRA, CBK-BSD are fully autonomous (in terms of legal autonomy, Operational/Budget independence),SASRA as a new regulator is less autonomous (mainly in terms of Operational/Budget independence). CBK as the key financial sectorregulator is operationally independent as provided under Article 231 of the Kenya Constitution of 2010 and enjoys a high degree ofeffective functional Independence with respect to its financial resources (Operational/Budgetary Independence) and choice ofInstruments and policies with regard to Monetary Policy target(s) set by the Finance Minister

title.narrative: Submission to Parliament of the transaction to dispose of State-influenced shares of National Bank of Kenya &Consolidated Bank.

baseline.value: NBK 22 percent by GoK; 48 percent by NSSF; CB 100 percent by GoK and State Corporations.

target.value: Plans for the privatization of GoK stakes in NBK and CB approved by Cabinet and submitted to Parliament.

comment.narrative: Target shouldnt be transaction completed as it depends on Parliament plus not to affect sale process.

Source: PMU, Privatization Commission, December 2012Detailed Privatization Proposal (and Draft Cabinet Memorandum) submitted toGovernment for approval (November 2009) in line with Privatization Act, 2005. New Privatization Commission (PC) Board GazettedOct.2012. The privatization status remains essentially unchanged since October 2011, in part due to delays in appointingPrivatization Commission Board (after Parliament rejected the last nominees), ongoing challenges between Treasury and NSSF inagreeing a formula for conversion of Preference Shares, and changes at NSSF (including in its top management). The project hasdelivered on the interventions and activities that it can support to take the Privatizations of the state influenced banks to thenext steps, which legally vetsin the PC, Cabinet and submission to/approval by, the relevant Parliamentary Committee.

title.narrative: Laws of Kenya revised and online access provided/enhanced with Judges Help Desk established and operational. Judges Help-Desk.

baseline.value: Real time information on the laws of Kenya not available online.

target.value: All Laws of Kenya Revised, and available in Hardcopy, CD-ROM, Online (in acceptable formats. Help Desk is established andoperational.

actual.value: All laws of Kenya Revised, and available in hardcopy (being cleared in customs expected shortly), CD-Rom, Online (in acceptableformats). Help Desk is established and operational.

comment.narrative: Source: PMU, March 2013

title.narrative: Financial Sector Regulators adopt Risk-Based Supervision.

baseline.value: Regulators at various stages in implementing RBS.CBK-BSD partially implemented RBS preparing risk management guidelines for FIs

actual.value: CBK, RBA, CMA, IRA and SASRA implementing RBS at different levels of progress.

comment.narrative: Source: PMU, Consultant (resident adviser) report; March 2013Sasra, the newest institutions created during the period of thFLSTAP and supported substantially by it, is also well on track towards RBS, while still at early stages of implementation given itis a new institution. It does have systems in place and manuals towards that end, increasing the natural pace of implementationexpected for new institutions. CBK-BSD has fully adopted Risk Based Supervision (RBS) for onsite and off-site surveillance ofbanks/Mortgage FIs/DTMs. CMA implementation of RBS and Training of staff in market operations and other directorates on RBS isongoing. CMA has developed a comprehensive risk profiling framework and submitted Risk Based Capital Adequacy Requirements to MoFfor approval. IRA adopted RBS as an intervention strategy and has implemented offsite and onsite surveillance. RBA has fullyimplemented RBS and is applying it to schemes (after an initial pilot on 60 schemes or 5% of total schemes). RBA ha

title.narrative: Percentage of population with access to formal rural financial services increases to at least 40 percent by end of project.

comment.narrative: This is an estimate of target at least 40%, to be confirmed, but supported by proxy data provided in Annex. FinAccess Survey beingcompleted, with data available in April/May. Based on proxies this is expected to be met. See note provided by the FLSTAP teamattached in missions section. FinAccess 2013 has been delayed (originally planned as FinAccess 2011) due to difficulties arisingfrom the last census and new/revised national sampling frame(s) introduced by KNBS. FINACCESS 2013 results are dueJune 2013, withearly results to be provided April 2013. These are most likely to indicate substantial increases in access to formal financialservices expected to exceed the target of 50% as of 31 December 2012 in line with massive increases in Accounts in banking systemfrom 2.5mn in 2005 to 17.6mn in 2012; continued penetration of Mobile banking particularly MPESA with over 15 million registeredsubscribers; introduction and licensing of eight (8) Deposit taking MFIs (DTMs); increase in Agent Bank

title.narrative: Percentage of population with access to formal financial services increases to 50 percent by end of project.

comment.narrative: At least 50%, based on proxies, but pending final confirmation. FinAccess Survey being completed, with data available inApril/May.Based on proxies this is expected to be met. See note provided by the FLSTAP team attached in missions section.

title.narrative: Private credit registries operational and sharing data.

target.value: Preparation for or drafting of regulations for Positive credit reporting and Drafting of Code of Conduct commences. Avg Numberofcredit reports accessed: 180,000

actual.value: Preparation for or drafting of regulations for Positive credit reporting and Drafting of Code of Conduct commences. 1,774,185 asof June 2012.Avg Number ofcredit reports accessed: 180,000

comment.narrative: Banking Act (Credit Reference Bureau) Regulations 2009 approved and operatinalised (Feb.2 009). Credit Information Sharing (CIS)launched in July 2010 resulted in licensing of 2 private Credit Reference Bureaus (CRBs). Credit reports requested by FIs totaled1,774,185 (year to 30 June 2012) compared to 728,553 reports (year to June 2011. The uptake of credit reports by regulated FIs isslowlybecoming entrenched in credit appraisal processes as Banks incorporate CRB reports in credit risk appraisal. CRBs and CIShelping banks to improve risk management processes and to price risks better based on risk profiles of customers. Project supportfor introduction of CIS has strengthened credit appraisal standards and contributed to steady reduction of NPLs even in the face ofeconomic andother shocks. CIS is assisting to inculcate a culture of repayment and discipline in credit utilization by borrowers,contributingtoan improved lending environment.

title.narrative: Percentage of clearing house transactions being processed through Real Time Gross Settlement rises to at least 95 percent.

comment.narrative: RTGS Backup site set uphandle s At least 95 percent of CH transactions.
No updated information is available for this ISR period.

title.narrative: Civil Procedure Rules reviewed and published.

actual.value: New Civil Procedure Rules (CPR) 2010 gazetted and in operation.

comment.narrative: Source: PMU, March 2013

title.narrative: Automation of recording and transcription services in at least the commercial and civil divisions of the High Court completed.

target.value: Automation of recording and transcription services completed in both divisions.

actual.value: Automation of recording and transcription services in its final days of completion in both divisions.

comment.narrative: Source: PMU, March 2013Most courts already delivered; final ones expected in the next few days, before project closure.

title.narrative: At least 15 new or upgraded Commercial/ Financial and related laws and subsidiary legislation developed, approved by Cabinet and published by the State Law Office (Attorney General’s Office)

comment.narrative: Complete stages of pending bills, regulations gazetted. 1-2 additional bills published (i.e. PPP bill 2011).

actual.value: List of Key Laws and Regulations developed, amended or Supported by Project: 1. Insurance (Amendment) Act 20062. MicrofinanceAct20063. Sacco Societies Act 20084. Banking Act (Credit Reference Bureau Regulations) 20085. Sacco Regulations 20106.MicrofinanceRegulations 20087. Civil Procedure Rules (CPR) 20108. Court of Appeal Rules 20109. Prevention of Terrorism Act 2012(CFT Law passed Oct.2012)10. Proceeds of Crime and Anti Money Laundering Act 200911. The Public Private Partnerships (PPP) Act2012 (regulations being finalized -stakeholder consultations in May 2013)12. Consumer Protection Law 2012 13. The PartnershipsAct, 201214. Limited Liability Partnership Act No 42 of 201115. Kenya Deposit Insurance Act 2011 (regulations completed, beingreviewed)16. NationalPayment System Act No 39 of 201117. Capital Markets Authority Bill18. Securities Bill19. CompaniesBill201220. Insolvency Bill201221. Capital Markets Regulations REITS22. Small Claims Court Bill, 2011

comment.narrative: source: PMU, March 2013
